On Wed, 4 Aug 2004 14:59:59 -0600 (MDT), "Clark I Anderson"
<anderci@...> said:
> 
> I am a JUnit novice as well as a JAVA novice.
> I have worked with ORACLE (not at the DBA level).
> Would it ba appropriate to trap this and other specific error
> codes and
> provide a response in English (e.g.: "server must be restarted")
> The DBA should be helpful in defining these codes - messages.
> Some 'occurrences' are beyond the control of the user in
> development, test
> or production.  User friendly guidance is important in all
> cases.

This isn't really a JUnit question.  It's a useability question.  Only
you and your organization can determine what the best approach here is,
however I will give you some PERSONAL advice.

The list of ORACLE errors that can possibly happen are extensive.  I
once catalogued these in code for Oracle 9i (I think that was the
version).  It turned out that the catalogue was not that useful because
most of the errors were not recoverable.  That code ended up being
refactored to capture the generic SQLException and turn it into a more
user-friendly message.  Our hint to what was really going on were the
logs.  So, as a matter of experience I would suggest to you that you do
not try to capture specifically coded errors unless there is something
you can do about it programmatically.  For instance, the user will most
likely not be interested in the fact that the database needs to be
restarted.  They just need to know that something went wrong, and
perhaps who to call when it happens.

Jason
